Actinomadura madurae is a species of actinobacteria, a group of Gram-positive, aerobic bacteria that are known for their ability to form branching filaments and spores. This bacterium was first isolated from cases of mycetoma, a chronic, progressive, and debilitating infectious disease that primarily affects the foot.

Actinomadura madurae is a slow-growing, non-acid-fast, and non-motile bacterium. It forms branching, septate, and pigmented (usually yellow to brown) aerial hyphae that can fragment into rod-shaped or coccoid elements. The bacterium is able to decompose a variety of organic compounds, including cellulose, and can grow on a wide range of media.

Actinomadura madurae is considered an opportunistic pathogen and is one of the causative agents of mycetoma, a neglected tropical disease that is characterized by the formation of subcutaneous granulomas, abscesses, and sinus tracts that discharge grains or granules. The disease is primarily found in tropical and subtropical regions, particularly in parts of Africa, Asia, and Latin America.

Understanding the biology and ecology of Actinomadura madurae is important for developing effective diagnostic and treatment strategies for mycetoma, as well as for furthering our knowledge of the diversity and functional roles of actinobacteria in the environment.
